WRITING.TITLE: Unemployed Wantrepreneur - What work can I do for you?
WRITING.TEXT: Unemployed Wantrepreneur - What work can I do for you? 2016 college grad, returning for an MBA in 2018 or 2019. I have a few business ideas I'd like to flesh out more within a grad program, and feel its especially important to get an MBA as a future self-employed entrepreneur. I'm 30, and have been continuously employed since 16. I majored in Parks and Recreation, with a business minor; my BS doesn't get me far in the business world. (One of those times I wish I had gotten that finance degree.) I recently lost my job and receive unemployment. This is the first time I've been fired. While it wasn't going great recently (a lot of changes, MIA management), it was a cornerstone of my MBA applications. I had been working hard for the past 18 mos., and now I can't even use them for a recommendation. Nothing wild happened, but the owner can be emotional, and fired several people over apparently nothing. I had been looking for another job anyway. Side note: I was in an accident 2 years ago that has left me with pain to manage, and a lot of debt. I was a student at the time of my accident, with low income, no insurance, and was on my own independently. Until the accident claim is over (i.e., settlement money), I can only do so much about the debt. Much of it is in collections, 2 companies have garnished wages. Long story short, I have an attorney and it should be resolved in the next 10 months, but I have no firm timeline beyond that. I explain this to say - I have no credit and very limited income, and this has been the case for a while. No friends or family can help out any more financially than they already have. Asking for a loan or anything along those lines is not an option unfortunately. I feel and have felt stuck because of the accident; I am no longer an able-bodied young person, and cannot start a business raking leaves or blowing snow singlehandedly. I don't even own a car. I have tried to put together small gigs, but ultimately I just don't have enough resources to grow. I can't explain how defeated and depressed I feel over it some days. I don't let it get me down, but what more can I do besides have a positive attitude? I am excited to get a good job. I want to make enough money to control of my life again. Like, 40k/ yr would be a dream. I need a job that: * pays $17+hr * remote or accessible by foot * relates to professional interests, pursuit of grad school I have worked in food, retail, small and large business. My interests include supply chain, finance and management, and background includes administration, retail and sales, animal welfare, and travel. I am currently: * applying for jobs * studying for the GMAT passively; I'll take as soon as I can afford to. * getting fit and focusing on physical recovery * reading business books * getting Google Ad Word certified - What else could I do like this? * building an online portfolio * Continually organizing notes and creating business plans, summaries, etc with friends/ partners **What I want right now is to pursue a more independent career and lifestyle, that keeps me on track to grad school and beyond.** I'd love to work remotely or independently. I am smart, savvy and resourceful. I'd be happy at an office job as well, so long as its more than answering phones and greeting people. I will have health insurance through my SO's provider starting in January, so I am open to independent contractor type of work. I cannot relocate until the accident claim is over, so while teaching english/ going abroad sounds great, it is not in the cards right now. I honestly feel a little aimless, continually doing all these things without more meaning behind it. Feedback and/or advice would be much appreciated! If you've got work you feel I could help with, please PM me!

WRITING.TITLE: Unbiased Reviews
CMV: We should not be asked to tip for coffee and other "to go" orders (US)
WRITING.TEXT: I understand that in a service environment, tipping is reasonably expected. Going to a restaurant or bar, getting a massage, etc, and being waiting on is an entirely different experience IMO to grabbing a $3 coffee or getting take out (i.e., pizza). Simply put, the food costs $20. I order the food and agree to pick it up. The agreement is $20 for food that I pick up. What am I tipping for? Is this not exactly what they advertise and what I agreed to? Food for $20? Why would they expect me to pay extra, when I didn't get anything exceptional? Again, if there is a delivery service, then I can understand the expectation of a tip. Furthermore, this is America, so I am not shocked that more companies are suggesting tips for their employees, because why not? However, I feel like we've really lost touch with the idea that tipping is OPTIONAL. While its customary, it can be rude to expect one. I find it kind of audacious that the pizza shop prints 15, 20 and 30% "suggested tip" amounts at the bottom of the receipt, as if I'd ever be inclined to tip 30% for a carry out order. Yeah, I enjoy this pizza place, but I'm not going to just give them extra money because of it. I'll keep going back and recommend them to others; I feel like this is a normal and reasonable approach to supporting a business. I feel that tipping for carry out is very much "tipping them for doing their job." On the other hand, when I am at a restaurant, I chat with the server, ask for food recommendations, and there's a level of engagement that makes me feel GOOD about leaving a tip, because I appreciated their help and they improved my experience. That is their job, but they served me as an individual, so it was still unique IMO, and worthy of a tip. Along those lines, when I've had bad service (wrong orders, no refills, forgetting silverware, etc) - I tip low or not at all, and sleep like a baby at night over it. Friends have argued that in many of these instances, the server is overworked and has too many tables, so its even more of an injustice to tip low. That argument solidifies my attitude of not tipping though, because tipping for poor service would encourage them to continue doing it; tipping is a way to show that everything is great and the experience was good. When I am inside of a place for 2 minutes, what are they expecting me to tip for? What am I saying when I don't tip, other than I don't believe there is a reason to tip? I am a regular at several coffee shops. I tip between $.50 and $1.00 depending on what I get, and when its under $3, I don't usually tip at all. I feel conflicted about this: on one hand, I am not comfortable tipping $.60 for an espresso, because its already ridiculous that they charge $3, and now its $4 with taxes amp; tip. On the other hand, I like this coffee shop and want to support it, so maybe tipping helps keep things moving. I don't want judgement from the staff, but really IDGAF about their judgement, I care about my coffee. If they want me to pay more for coffee, just raise your prices. If their employee's pay is based on "optional" tipping, then its not a sustainable business model, and I wouldn't want to support that anyway. I'm trying not to dive deeper into tipping culture as a whole, but I do want to acknowledge that in previous discussions I've had about this, the opposing side often suggested: if I have a problem tipping, then don't go to places that ask for tips. This seems ideal, but its not realistic; its everywhere! I'd have to go out of my way to avoid it, and furthermore, tipping is OPTIONAL (unless you're 8+ party, etc). A big part of my job is meeting clients, and I have yet to find any place that doesn't ask for tips, regardless of what food/drink/ service they offer. While there is an idea that you should walk in anticipating you'll tip 20%, I just don't. I tip what I feel is reasonable, and feel its audacious to assume I'll tip 20% just because. TL;DR: I feel like an asshole, but would feel like sucker for tipping on unexceptional experiences. I don't want to close myself off from the world of coffee shops and carry out thai, but WTF is the deal with expecting a tip for (seemingly) nothing? P.S. Yes, I have spent time in Europe and prefer their approach to food service and food service careers. I would love to see servers get paid well, for the price to just BE the price, and for the experience to be more about the food and less about how many tables the server is juggling. I understand that there is a difference, and in America being a server can be an amazing opportunity to make good money (mostly tax-free). However, it find it impertinent that the foundation of food businesses expect their customers to pay the employees, on top of the premium prices for the food. Its a broken business model. _____ gt; *This is a footnote from the CMV moderators. We'd like to remind you of a couple of things. Firstly, please* ***[read through our rules](http://www.reddit.com/r/changemyview/wiki/rules)***. *If you see a comment that has broken one, it is more effective to report it than downvote it. Speaking of which,* ***[downvotes don't change views](http://www.reddit.com/r/changemyview/wiki/guidelines#wiki_upvoting.2Fdownvoting)****! Any questions or concerns? Feel free to* ***[message us](http://www.reddit.com/message/compose?to=/r/changemyview)***. *Happy CMVing!*

So like, personally, I am wearing a makeshift tube top kind of bra. It's 2 different stretchy bras from Target that I just pulled the straps down with. My shoulders can't take the weight or pain any more. I have pain shooting up my back. My whole left side seems to ache from the lack of support, but I just can't wear the weight on my shoulders anymore. I plan to go to a doctor soon to seek a referral for breast reduction. I didn't want to go this route but I honestly haven't found a well fitting bra in over a year. My best fitting bra is a 34J; I don't fill in the cups at the top in a weird way, the underwire pokes and rubs and hurts, and the lace surrounding it it's godawful itchy. I think it's made entirely of polyester, it's absolutely miserable to wear. But I wore it for a year and lately it's only used in desperation with formal dresses, since I need something. I am working on a bra and underwear company concept to address these kind of pain points, but fast fashion amp; lingere is saturated industry. It will take me years to truly manufacture good bras. Oh god I know a couple who had an 'engagement ceremony', if that's what you could call it. They had been dating since high school, and were now ~22. She was this insecure and aggressive type of person. He was a total teddy bear and I chronically felt bad for how mean she seemed to be to him. She started to become really overbearing and pressuring him to propose around the time he was graduating college and looking at grad school (out of state, where she didn't want to go). She planned his proposal for her. I still don't understand it. I got an invitation and everything. They had a party some Saturday, something like a formal potluck. He was scheduled to pop the question in a room at 2:00pm. It sounded absolutely cringy and awful. I refused to attend this or their actual (another sad story) wedding, solely because of the principal of how *weird* she treated him. I'd say different strokes for different folks, but she gave me the willies. I was a few years older than them at the time and had been divorced at 23 from a psycho abuser. She had so many red flags. He went on to go to grad school at his alma mater/ her hometown. They had a baby recently. I still feel bad for that guy. She seemed to suck all happiness from everything and he was in too deep to get out.

WRITING.TITLE: How to delete ALL photos from device?
WRITING.TEXT: I have 10GB of photos and videos on my device. They have been backed up. Tapping "free up space" does not show 10GB of backed up videos and photos; it just shows a few MB now. I would like to remove all of these photos, but the only option seems to be manually selecting photos by their date and then tapping "remove from device." I have found threads addressing the question but no answer on the manual removal of each file by date. I even have it plugged into my laptop but cannot locate these files in the same way they are shown on my phone. Thanks!
Yes that is exactly where the majority of photos seemed to be. It's strange that I can back up these photos but they somehow remain after "cleaning up space."

I was able to remove photos by deleting the DCIM folder, as well as other folders like instagram and whatsapp media. Leaving this comment and post here in hopes someone can stumble across it in the future.

WRITING.TITLE: I finally found a bra that fits - but I cannot stand the underwire (34J)
WRITING.TEXT: Godbless Curvy Kate, I am so happy to have found some relief. My breasts have grown recently and I have been unable to find a good fit for months. My breasts just ache. The thing is, the underwire is impossibly uncomfortable. (I've had this experience will Panache bras as well). I do not understand how ANYONE can tolerate this! I am really at a loss; is there NO HOPE for J cups if you find underwire painful or suffocating? It digs into my ribs under my breasts, and they POKE ME from end to end! I wore this curvy kate bikini top (somehow it was easier to find a 34J bathing suit bra??) ~7 times in 2 weeks, and the underwire actually popped out (from the top of the cup, at the center of my chest). IN 2 WEEKS. I intend to get a breast reduction, but that isn't as quick of a fix as just finding a good bra, right?

Thanks so much for the feedback. The wires actually popped from a 34JJ, which was a bit too large in the cups but generally a welcome level of support. I bought it out of desperation because other 34J's were a weird fit, and I would wear the bra over a t-shirt to pad the wires, especially at my chest. Since it at least helped my breast pain, I went ahead and ordered a 34J. While waiting for it to arrive, the JJ wires popped. I got the 34J today and its a bit more snug, but the underwires are completely uncomfortable! For a moment, sure I can wear it, but I cannot stand wearing this even 30 mins without absolutely fidgeting with all 4 corners of the underwire + the pain of the wire hitting my ribs.

Thanks so much for your thorough reply! I agree that this size isn't the most convenient for finding good bras. I guess I am very projected and have a full shape. I've never fit into plunge styles because my boobs just pop or slip out. I have always kind of found of the sides of underwire uncomfortable - am I crazy? I cannot help but notice exactly where the underwire ends. They often flex and move as I move, and I usually tuck my shirt into the edge of the bra to help make a buffer. I tended to wear the same Natori bras year after year (until I outgrew them #128557;) because they were some of the only fits I could wear 8-10 hours. Otherwise I was in XXL sports bras. This bra was the ONLY bra I have found (in years) that actually touches my sternum like they are "supposed to;" for me, most bras are super flimsy at the center and are swimming in cleavage. Curvy Kate has been the best fit I have found in 2 years, and it's not even tolerable. It's so miserable wasting so much time and money.

Thank you so much for the offer to take a look at my measurements! I am away from home and my measuring tape right now, so I will message you again tomorrow. I really appreciate the long response, it's really helpful. I think you are pretty spot on about the wide root and projection; I don't quite know how to describe them, but they are big and heavy and full. The tissue is more firm than soft. They are also pretty round and centered, in that cone shape bras are a total misfit. I think you're right that I probably have more breast tissue on my side that might be where it pokes. I have found my favorite bras are ones that have underwire rest further back under my arm.

Different culture and medical system. I'm an American who has lived abroad and currently in Germany; it's WILD how different medicine is around the world. For example, I have never gotten an exam in Germany, despite getting controlled substances and other prescriptions. No one cares about my temperature, blood pressure or current medications. They do no general checks or ask questions before discussing my issues (like feeling ill for days), which I always find ODD because a fever is a significant indicator. I have rarely ever even been touched by a doctor in my worst moments of pain or illness. The US has the best standards of practice worldwide, I am certain.

I'd be happy to! Key things about quality of life in Europe: - reasonable days off, which is also socially/ culturally acceptable. US work culture is toxic even at the best companies. - easy access amp; acceptance of healthy travel and recreation options; i.e., beaches, mountains, boating, biking, horse riding, skiing, etc, which is also pretty culturally ingrained as typical hobbies. Only in select areas in the US do you get acces to that, and there is a cost/ exposure barrier for much of the middle class. - low cost of living options. Food is subsidized in Germany and is wildly affordable. Every thing has been inflating beyond the wages and I just could never save money as an adult. - socialism. Society benefits when people all have access to basic healthcare. I was living the grind life when I first came to Europe 5 years ago. I could barely afford the trip. I had never taken a family vacation or any trip of this sort before. (My parents both worked in management and literally never got PTO in their 20 year career.) I was in over 30k in student loan debt with being 1/2 thru my program; I was planning to go onto medical school because I wanted to make as much money as possible to pursue FIRE. I already felt burnt out working 2 PT jobs while in school FT pursuing premed, and was seriously concerned about my future (the kind of the person I'd become to be successful). I was unsure if I wanted to keep going this path, and had always thought living in Europe would be an impossible dream. Whle the trip big deal on it's own, what immediately struck me when I got to traveling was how "free" everyone actually seemed to be. - drink beer all over the place, and people are generally responsible and respectful. - a holiday weekend where the whole city seemed to be celebrating. It was an elating experience (King's Day NL) - none of this taxes and tipping BS. Also, less upselling and aggressive sales tactics. Finally. - small talk is generally kept to a minimum, whereas Americans can be weirdly chatty and also weirdly judgemental. I spent 3 weeks in: Oslo, Amsterdam, Nice, Cinque Terre, Zurich, Vienna, Stuttgart and left from Cologne. I can home and vowed to leave the US. I did so 4 years later and have no idea when I'll leave here.

WRITING.TITLE: US Citizen-resided abroad for 9 months in 2019 and only made money abroad. What taxes are due to US?
WRITING.TEXT: Working with H amp;R Block, they have gone back and forth a bit (several agents have taken over this case) on what I owe and they still haven't been able to break it down or itemize how they got to $3k. $3k is fine, but its a bit higher than I expected given my income. I have been so wrapped up in moving to a new country and covid, I cannot think straight, and H amp;R Block has never made me feel too confident. **Relevant info:** * 15,000 Gross income (Germany) * 4500: 401K EW (paid 450 at the time/ Jan 2019) * 5600: Unemployment *3,200: Tax due* I collected unemployed for the first few months of 2019, (withdrew 401K for emergency), and eventually moved out of the country (EU) for the rest of the year. I have a 1099 from a US company that I worked remotely for since relocating. Its my EU address on my 1099. Out of curiosity: if I already paid the 10% penality for early withdrawal, how else do these taxes add up to $3200? Many thanks!
Ah ok, but thanks for clarifying the 401k. Self employment tax is 15%. There should be no state or other local taxes, since this income was not generated in any US region, right?

I was the first ex-wife in this instance. I was contacted by a newer ex; here's my story. We had been divorced about 1-2 years, after being separated for 18 month beforehand (so it's been 3-4 since I had spoken to his fool). He had BPD, was controlling, manipulative, possessive. Physically and verbally abusive. Chronic liar. When we got married, the mask came off - it was absolutely bizarre but also very textbook apparently. Couples therapy helped me because I was advised to get out asap, and eventually I took that advice. He didn't let me go after the divorce finalized. He had key loggers and spyware on all my devices; he was a software engineer. I was as 24, he was 26. He went crazy, honestly. I knew he was still actively stalking me, as he had shown up at my work and would send messages to various reddit accounts and emails. I guess he was dating, and was an awful guy (surprise surprise). He had begun making $$$ as I was leaving him (I took nothing in our divorce), and he apparently becamevery flashy with buying gifts, new cars, travels, I dunno, he seemed to be filling a hole. I didn't know this guy. In our relationship, bad things slowly escalated over 3 years. For the newer ex who reached out to me some 3-4 years after I left him - he was terrifyingly abusive. He pushed her down stairs (multiple times), pushed her out a moving car, left her places... And they only dated 9 months before she felt desperate to talk to someone about him, because of his gaslighting and lying to others. He would twist stories to be the victim, make you apologize to him, then abuse you an hour later. She contacted me. I got creeped out. Read her messages and thought it over for a few days. Agreed to a one-time conversation with her over text. We talked for about 4 hours. It was awful. I was sickened and drained. I still haven't forgotten about the things she said happened. But I reassured her, we kind of comisserated, and then I encouraged her to file a police report and a restraining order (my biggest regret) against him. And asked her to never contact me again. Bonus: we had the same first name. HE WAS SUCH A CREEP. *Edited for clarity

Ok, going on a limb here: if you have sprinklers, set them to motion activation. George will be spooked by the water and ideally associate your yard with scary random sprinklers over a short time. You can put it on a timer, so it only goes off at night or during certain hours when your cats are not as likely to be outside as well (unless you want to scare them off your yard, too). This involves a little extra work, but it definitely works over time. I have battled neighborhood cats for years, and besides a hose in the moment, motion sensitive lights and water tend to spook troublemakers from coming back over and over. Eventually you don't have to keep the settings like that; just for a brief ~1-3 months until George officially backs off.

WRITING.TITLE: Sensory options for 34J/JJ(UK)
WRITING.TEXT: Hi my boobyfriends, I have found a [well-fitting bra in 34J](https://www.bravissimo.com/products/maya-bra-ln655/#black-ln655blk) (hallejujah). However, the fabric is so uncomfortable and irritating that I am convinced I need to seek out sensory bras at this point. I purchased 5 bras from Bravissimo ranging from 34, 36J/JJ and this is the only one I can stand wearing; it doesn't create more pain or aching in my chest over time, and the straps are nice on my shoulders. Overall, I really like this bra because it seems to be best for my frame. The front-center gore actually reaches my chest (though it pokes and irritates so much that I must but a sock or something inbetween to protect my skin). It fits perfectly, but I cannot stand the fabric or the feeling of the underwire, just as they are. I cannot help but notice all the fabric on these bras are just... unacceptable. I am wearing tank tops under to buffer the polyester fabric from my skin (which as been a huge relief as stupid looking as it is), especially whereever the underwire meets my skin. Any suggestions for a 34-36 rib cage and J+ cups? I am tired of the shoulder and neck pain associated with bad straps, stiff giant bras that I need help to put on, have trouble breathing in (compression all over my ribs and chest), and cannot bear to wear while sitting to work. I'm looking for a camisole (does someone do memory foam camis yet??) or any product that would actually fit this 34JJ size. Any recommendations are appreciated! **I am DYING for something where I have little/ no cleavage. I want everything covered and supported, up to my breast line/ modest look.** P.S. Looking to get into sewing honestly, to just make my own. I am already frankenstien monstering my bras...

WRITING.TITLE: How to politely decline wedding help from parents over the next 6 months
WRITING.TEXT: My parents are lovely, helpful, and mean well - but I rarely ask for their help, and they tend to give unsolicited help and advice that I find taxing. It's a lot of "Thanks but no thank you"s that I try not to feel too guilty about. My parents have had a tendency to give unwanted/ troublesome gifts at times, and over the years I've found a decent balance; Sometimes I say no thanks, and sometimes I indulge them. And sometimes, their help is really great! I understand its a love language that they like to do acts of service and give gifts. This is a decent compromise to keep family relationships peaceful. I know they mean well and I don't want to hurt their feelings. My mom and dad have both come to me with cute little ideas, but much of it is either 1) way too early to discuss right now/ something I do not want to make a firm decision on yet 2) a bad interpretation of the little things I have asked them to help with, or 3) totally unwanted and unsolicited help/ ideas/ 'do you want me to buy this for your wedding?' - which is the worst and weirdest to respond to, because I usually need to reply in a hurry. That being said, we do not really see eye-to-eye on taste and style, and furthermore, they keep trying "help" in ways that I find inappropriate given their role in our wedding. I have had to say 'no' a lot, or redirect their idea/ gift concept to something more useful/ practical/ desirable. **My wedding is ~8 months away**, and I don't need much help with it until its ~3 months away. We are shooting for a smaller, simple, under 10k kind of wedding, and as much - at this time, there is little to do in preparation for it (besides lose weight amp; tone up, am i rite?). We have our venue reserved and made an announcement; I plan to send formal invitations around February/ March which gives guests 3+ months notice, with a 6 week confirmation window before the big day. Most help is needed the weekend of the wedding itself (several people, hands-on), with some basic 'Can I have this mailed to you and you bring it?' kind of coordinating. I am relying on my bridal party to help with a few odd things, and have asked both of my parents to do something special for me/ us for our wedding, which they are happy to do but - it doesn't need to be done until next spring. It's way too early for them to help with anything else I have in mind. While I appreciate them coming to me with these odd things, I am already tired of saying "No thanks/ its too early to plan that/ I don't really care for that look/ etc." First and foremost, I feel bad. I understand they are only trying to help, but its often a hassle. **tl;dr: How do I keep politely saying 'NOOOOOOO STAP IT EVERYTHING IS FINE AND LETS DISCUSS THIS MORE IN THE SPRING FOR THE LOVE OF GOD'**

Things they have suggested/ offered include: * - wacky venue recommendations that do not suit the event * - help in choosing our wedding rings * - types of food we should have in the reception * - various font types we could/ should use in wedding correspondence * - various cake toppers they could order for us I feel like they genuinely want to help, but also project their expectations of my wedding, as if they get any say in it.
Excellent, thank you. That is simple enough, and hopefully sends the message that "we are not making decisions like this yet/ wait until next spring when its more relevant."
How much is that in dollary-doos?

That's a great suggestion. The wedding venue is a destination for everyone unfortunately, and them both being present for 2+ days is already impossible; they refuse to leave their pets in anyone else's care, so attending the wedding itself is really all I can ask of them surrounding the wedding day. I am trying to think of something I can put them on, but the thing is - I really do want to keep it simple. They want to give a ton of energy to something, and its just not yet the time to. I will just encourage them to wait until the new year to really discuss things, and will put them on a project as soon as there is something for them to do.

I am racking my brain for a small project like this, but to be honest, I think it would only complicate things; their questions would increase 10 fold, even if I told them it was their call. I really don't know what to give them (at this time anyway!). In a way its funny; they keep making suggestions on things that my SO and I have happen to have already discussed or agreed on in some manner - so their input is just not needed (and was never asked for, so I feel blindsided by them a lot). The cake for example - we plan to do cupcakes, with 1 small cake for just the wedding party *maybe*. A cake topper discussion is a headache with them, because I don't need to justify what we already intend to do. If we do get a cake topper, we already have a few in mind (that I would probably just put on display in a different way, if that makes sense). I don't even know how to explain that I already have cake topper plans - my plans are still in a maybe phase, but I just don't need their input/ help choosing it. I will ask my mom and dad, separately and casually, if there are any wedding traditions they would like to see or help with, and then let them talk. Hopefully that will help get some ideas going.

Yeah, I would LOVE to give them a job like the seating chart. It's just not something they can do in the next 6 months. It would require RSVP's, and with covid-19 and the wedding being in 8 months... that project is so far away, I don't even know what kind of table or chairs we will be renting yet (i.e., how many can fit at a table, etc).

gt; This is your wedding though, so try not to be too accommodating just to keep the peace. You #8217;ll regret it later if it #8217;s not what you want. This is exactly the concern I have; I know they are just excited and happy for us and want it to be special, but its adding so much unnecessary pressure to make me constantly say "no I do not like that" to such random things. I don't want to hurt their feelings, especially over a wedding!, but I cannot abide by all these ideas they throw at me. We got engaged last year, set the date 5 months ago lmao. They are just getting excited that the date is finally within view; they have been giving me wedding tips since we chose the venue/ set the date 5 months ago. We still have 9 more months to go now.
452 crunchy/ soft tacos, or 321 cheesy gordita crunches.

Yeah I totally agree with you on the last paragraph. I know it seems ungrateful to say this, and I am very grateful for their love, support, and interest. I want to steer them in the right direction when I can, and say no nicely when I have to. I just feel like I am getting more and more bombarded with random questions. I know my wedding (and by extension, my lifestyle) are not quite what they would want for me. I moved far away from my family and home state when I was 18, and now live across the country (CA amp; NY distance). With covid, there will be no dress fittings with moms or anyone in the wedding party/ family except for my MOH, as she is the only one that lives near me. I had planned to fly out this month to attend another wedding, then squeeze in some dress fittings w/ mom and cousins before flying back, but things change and everything was cancelled. This sucks, but it is what it is. I cannot afford to visit my parents any time before a few days prior to our wedding. This makes planning and doing things with them hard. I am planning my wedding from afar; my parents don't live in a city of want to get married in/ make everyone come travel to, so I chose location a few hours away from them that is nice for everyone to come visit. And it's on the beach, which is our dream. The venue itself it's inherently troublesome for my parents to get to, but any venue would have been unless we got married within an hour of their home. I think I need to give them an updated timeline on the wedding planning, with some juicy details and requests for feedback, so they have a better idea of what I have in mind now. One project I can probably put them on early is flowers; I have very little preference on flowers besides color. Maybe they can have field day with that...

Colonoscopies are the best! I was severely constipated for over 2 weeks. I had not had a proper shit in over 10 days. Every OTC recommendation from a doctor did fuck all, and at one point I doubled all doses for days on end (per DR orders) to try to get some movement. Nothing. Worked. I was at day 14 of no BM. Finally they scheduled a colonoscopy. I was absolutely sick and in distress, and couldn't wait for this procedure so I could get some answers. 2 days before the test, they call me to pick up an RX for me to take the day before the procedure, along with some rules about fasting. The RX is a literal gallon container, with some powder at the bottom. I add water and drink. It's hard to guzzle down a whole gallon of a thing in one sitting, but I powered through. Holy hell, relief had arrived. By the time I got to the hospital for the colonoscopy, I felt much, much better. I was absolutely estastic. I still went along with the procedure, but it turned up nothing remarkable. It was honestly chill and relaxing. Absolutely worth it and highly recommend.

As others have said, 1) rule out a UTI/ health issue and 2) give her additional things in the crate to ease anxiety and make it more her safe place. I can add, if she's getting enough potty breaks, I'd consider a diet (food and/or frequency) adjustment. For example, feed her 2x a day instead of 3, so she gets on a regular #2 schedule. Then if she messed in the night, it's not likely shitty. If she continues to urinate in the night after a trip to the vet, some familiar clothes/ cuddle toys added to her crate, and a diet review/ adjustment... Then give her more exercise daily so that she's so tired she sleeps through the night. She is old enough to hold it 8-10 hours. Be sure to offer her 4-6 potty breaks daily. Give her love and reassurance. She probably just needs some time to adjust to a new home.

I barely graduated high school, started college when I was 24, and just completed my MBA as a B/C student. I got better grades my last 2 years of undergrad (nearly had a straight A semester!), but ended up with a 2.9 GPA upon graduating. Grades didn't effect me too much, because I had a lot of shit going on in my personal life in high school and throughout college. I didn't not make a great effort in graduate school honestly, and have a lower GPA (which I don't give a shit about. I don't want a job if they want my grades.) I have a lot of soft skills and interview well because of life experience. I know how to start a business, can hire or fire an attorney, and have a confidence in my decision making that most peers seems to lack still. I usually can land any job I can get interviewed in person for. Underprivileged kids often don't get good grades if their home life is unstable. I had good reasons for low grades and always had extra curriculars (work experience, hobbies, volunteering, etc) to show for it. Somehow, I am always able to convince someone my grades don't fully represent my worth.
Best wishes!

My SO is chill with whatever is best. What would you do? Edit: The wedding is abroad/ in our home country; we are both currently living in Europe and are from the US. I figure we could push the wedding back by 3-6 weeks. She says she really wants to attend it/ see her family there as well, but I am not sure if she ultimately want to fly with a baby next summer (covid wont be gone by then, ya know?). I'm just not sure how to have my wedding w/o her there!
